It does take two messages, not necessarily two round trips. The SDK could send the clear and then the append message without waiting for the clear to be processed. The SDK could also choose to send one and then wait and then send the second one.

The order of the messages on the stream are applied in the order they are received and gRPC guarantees message delivery order.
LGTM. Thanks.

https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3313

Why we cannot simply merge master into this branch? There should be no conflicts of any kind. (Not a rebase, just a merge.)

If we do this, and there was any merge issue, actual work could be permanently lost!

Generally speaking, I think we should be rebasing pull requests -- they represent a little piece of work by the same author -- likelihood of a bad merge is small. For feature branches, however, I think we should just merge, not rebase. If we rebase, sooner or later, somebody will make an error, and we'll lose data with a force push.

@rangadi @jkff removing `CoderBasedKafkaSerializer` without providing an alternative seems like a bit of a regression in terms of being able to read Avro from Kafka out of the box. Would it make sense to ship serializer/deserializer classes for Avro in `kafka/serialization`?
Ok. Let me force push with a merge.
@XuMingmin I don't see any reason why doing this in two steps. Simply what I did just worked on my branch. Let me just do a merge and update this PR.

@peay My understanding was that there exists a standard Serializer/Deserializer for Avro in the Kafka ecosystem (https://github.com/confluentinc/schema-registry/tree/master/avro-serializer/src/main/java/io/confluent/kafka/serializers) so we don't need to provide our own.

The two-steps means 1) a direct pull request from master branch to DSL_SQL branch, merge it by ignoring any build errors as nothing in  master relies on SQL, then 2) another PR to upgrade versions, fix any potential error.

The existing PR has too many changes there, 10s of thousands lines, from both master/sql branches, it's hard to do a review.

Mingmin
Sent from my iPhone

@peay The first version of the patch kept `CoderBasedKafkaSerializer` ( https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2986/commits/89a840a9291dc8de2462e4ce76293d84a24f06f0 ) and added utility methods (`readerWithCoders()' & `writerWithCoders()`). These are a bit complex because of need to support coders of any type. It is much simpler to add own Serializer based a specific coder.

Would an example (perhaps in in tests) help? We could point to that in JavaDoc.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11874107/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11874107)

Coverage increased (+0.01%) to 70.632% when pulling **bba7ab184477ccdc9dd026690cee5ef7bab052fb on aljoscha:flink-shutdown-on-infinite-watermark** into **609016d700c84800cf942482fb7cd2ddaa420b00 on apache:master**.

@jkff this is actually what I mostly use, but I believe this only supports serialization/deserialization with a Confluent Schema Registry, which uses a special wire format that includes a reference to the Avro schema registered into the Schema Registry.

Serializing raw Avro (i.e., without Avro container binary format or schema registry payload) to a topic requires you to keep track of what's in there yourself if you want to read it later, but this can be useful and not everyone uses a schema registry, which made using `KafkaIO + CoderBasedKafkaSerializer/AvroCoder` convenient.

One option indeed would be to add some documentation/examples on how to make a custom serializer/deserializer based on a coder as suggested by @rangadi.

Alternatively, if you feel that recommending to wrap coders still clashes too much with the style guide, maybe Beam could ship with a lightweight serializer/deserializer pair that directly uses Avro's `DatumWriter/DatumReader`? Beam has good integration with Avro across the board, so I think it would be consistent to provide some basic Avro support built in `KafkaIO` out of the box. This would also make migration from Beam <= 0.6 easier.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11874131/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11874131)

Coverage decreased (-0.1%) to 70.497% when pulling **e06ac4bcf4b44af3c4a0e890f3299f84ca8051cd on lukecwik:fn_api2** into **78b6e3cddc5feb882e184a4bfce3af73eeee9a33 on apache:master**.
+1 for Avro serializers and deserializer, either based on coders or directly implemented. Based on coders might be better (will also serve as a simple example of using coders as serializers).
It does not need to be part of KafkaIO.java proper. Just in the same package is fine.

R: @davorbonaci 
CC: @jbonofre  @xumingming
@davorbonaci, could you merge this directly? I'll follow with another PR to solve the errors.
LGTM, thanks a lot for this one.

Please, no using coders as serializers. The only reason this question keeps coming up at all is that currently all the fancy and convenient Avro/Proto stuff implemented by the Coder's is usable only through the Coder's themselves, and is not packaged as a library proper.

The right thing to do here is:
1) refactor AvroCoder and ProtoCoder into utility classes, making AvroCoder and ProtoCoder themselves simply thin wrappers over those
2) introduce Kafka serializers/deserializers that also use those utility classes

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11876020/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11876020)

Yes, that sounds good. 90% of the code in `AvroCoder` is to check for determinism anyway, serialization itself is essentially just a oneliner along the lines of `(new GenericDatumWriter<>(schema)).write(value)`.
